Choosing the right franchise is a big decision.

Before you sign on the dotted line, make sure you get answers to these important questions:

 What's the total investment? Understand the franchise fee, startup costs, and ongoing expenses. 

 What kind of training and support is provided? Look for comprehensive training and ongoing support. 

 What are the franchise agreement terms? Know the length of the agreement, renewal options, and what happens if things don't go as planned. 

 How will the franchisor help with site selection? Location is key! Make sure they offer support in finding the right spot. 

 What does a successful franchisee look like? Gain insights into the traits and skills needed to thrive. 

Do your homework and ask the tough questions! Want some help? Contact us for a free consultation!

Taking initiative means stepping forward before you're asked, solving problems before they escalate, and creating opportunities instead of waiting for them.

Gist time 

This morning, I celebrated 1,000 followers (whoop whoop! ).

At first, I wasnâ€™t even going to celebrate it.

Why?

Because it was part of my January goal, and now that Iâ€™m aiming higher, it felt small (donâ€™t judge me! ).

But then I reminded myself: Celebrate your wins, no matter how small.

Plus, my impressions have been doing press-ups since Monday, so I figured, why not?

Excitedly, I hit "Post," sat back, and waited for the magic to happen.

Thenâ€¦ 12 likes. 8 comments. 1 repost. In one whole hour. 

Me, who had big dreams for this post, immediately thought: DELETE. DELETE. DELETE.

But just as I was about to remove it, I paused and thought 

Some days, your posts will go viral.
Some days, theyâ€™ll flop.
Thatâ€™s just how it works.

So instead of deleting, I let it be. And guess what? It picked up later, but not as I expected.

What I learned:
 Detach from the outcome.
 Keep showing up.
 Keep sharing.

Some days will surprise you, others will humble you, but consistency always wins.

postsData.content:
It's time for some real talk about how we respond to uncertainty, change and even chaos around us.

 Do you find yourself taking the bait and easily getting emotionally hijacked, reactive and even freaking out? Or do you regulate in a way that better serves you, others and the situation?

It's Thought-Provoking Thursday and time for another Rosie-in-my-Pocket...

The reality is that, while it's normal and human to be reactive, it's not usually helpful and leads to messes we have to clean up later. So remember this...

 CALM is your leadership superpower! 

Here's how you find it:
1ï¸âƒ£ Breathe. The best source of calm is our breath. So pause and take a few deep breaths; this will chill out your nervous system.

2ï¸âƒ£ Ask yourself: "Do I actually have enough information to freak out here?" (this can be a tough one because we will convince ourselves we do when the reality is we have pieces of information and are filling in the rest with assumptions, fears and story)

3ï¸âƒ£ If "yes" to #2, Ask yourself: "Will freaking out here actually be helpful or might it make things worse?"

I have found myself leaning on these 3 over and over lately, and it's been really helpful to find calm and create a space of clarity so I can continue focusing on what I can control and the difference and impact I can make around me.

 What have you noticed when you put these 3 steps into practice? Or how else do you quiet the reactivity? I'd love to hear it - drop your thoughts in the comments.

comments.commentText:
Such a powerful reminder! Itâ€™s so easy to get caught up in the chaos, but taking a pause to breathe and check the story weâ€™re telling ourselves makes all the difference. Do your research and gather the facts.

I currently live by this quote from Angela Davis: "I am no longer accepting the things I cannot change. I am changing the things I cannot accept."

And, when I pause and gather the facts first, then I can proceed with calm determination rather than freaking out.

postsData.content:
THE DEATH OF THE TRADITIONAL CIO/CTOs

FROM SYSTEMS TO SOULS
Why AI Demands a New Breed of Leader

As artificial intelligence reshapes business, a study by Forester of over 500 organizations reveals that 75% of enterprises attempting to build AI agents in 2025 will fail to achieve their goals under traditional technology leadership. This demonstrates the urgent need for a new leadership model that bridges technical expertise with human insights.

 WHAT'S NEW

 Traditional CIO/CTO roles prove insufficient for managing modern AI systems that adapt and evolve through user interaction

 A new leadership role - Chief Innovation and Transformation Officer (CITO) - bridges technical expertise with human insights

 Success with AI requires managing both systems and souls: technical implementation and human/cultural transformation

 Organizations need structured frameworks for implementing and governing AI that account for both technical and human dimensions

 BEYOND TECHNICAL EXPERTISE
THE NEED FOR A NEW LEADERSHIP MODEL

As we discussed in â€œTRANSCENDâ€, the challenge of implementing AI effectively extends far beyond technical prowess.

Leaders responsible for AI implementation must be able to:

 Navigate Complex Ethical Landscapes: AI deployment requires careful consideration of ethical implications, bias mitigation, and alignment with organizational values.

 Foster Cultural Transformation: Successfully integrating AI means transforming organizational culture to embrace new ways of working and thinking.

 Manage Human-AI Collaboration: Leaders must understand both human psychology and AI capabilities to create effective partnerships between human workers and AI systems.

 Drive Cross-Functional Integration: AI implementation touches every part of an organization, requiring leaders who can work across traditional silos.

 Ensure Responsible Innovation: Leaders must balance the drive for innovation with careful consideration of potential risks and societal impacts.

Traditional CIO and CTO roles, with their focus on technical implementation and system maintenance, are not structured to address these broader challenges. This misalignment helps explain why so many AI initiatives will fail to achieve their goals.

This Robotic Foot Is a Masterpiece of Robotics & Engineering.

The SoftFoot Pro, a prosthetic foot, It works without motors, just pure engineering genius, copying how a real foot moves.

Here's why it's so special:

1/ It has a built-in mechanism that stores and releases energy, just like our feet do.

2/ It adapts to uneven ground, something regular prosthetics struggle with.

3/ It's lightweight but super strong, supporting up to 100kg.

4/ It's basically AI, but in its purest form, not software, but smart design.

This is biomimicry at its finest. We're learning from nature to build tech that moves and balances just like us. It's a foot designed for humans, but also for the future of robots.

What other human abilities do you think technology should try to copy next?

5 proven methods to develop a growth mindset.
(Backed by decades of science.)

Success isn't about talent. It's about your mindset.

After studying peak performers and diving into neuroscience.

Ive discovered growth isnâ€™t just positive thinking.

Itâ€™s a systematic approach backed by decades of research.

Most try forcing growth through willpower. Science shows a smarter path.

Here are 5 research-backed methods that transformed my life:

1ï¸âƒ£ Pause and Reflect
Take a moment to process the situation. Your brain rewires during reflection.

 Daily action: 10-minute journal. Ask "What did today teach me?"

2ï¸âƒ£ Reframe the Narrative
Change your focus from â€œI failedâ€ to â€œIâ€™m learning.

 Daily action: Add "yet" to your limitations. "I can't" becomes "I can't yet."

3ï¸âƒ£ Adjust and Strategize
Pinpoint what didnâ€™t work and create a new plan. Failure is just rewiring your neural pathways.

 Daily action: Turn big goals into small experiments.

4ï¸âƒ£ Take Action and Persist
Grit beats talent. Keep moving forward with purpose and determination.

 Daily action: One small step forward. Every day.

5ï¸âƒ£ Celebrate Small Wins
Progress triggers dopamine. Motivation follows. Acknowledge every step forward, no matter how small.

 Daily action: List three wins before bed.

The truth? Growth isn't about big leaps. It's about small, scientific steps.

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned:

The messiest times in life often lead to the most growth.

12 Power Phrases for Your Toughest CEO Moments
(exact words that put you back in control)

High-stakes moments make or break CEOs.

Your next words can change everything.

Most CEOs freeze in critical moments.
They fear saying the wrong thing.

But power isn't in perfect words - it's in shifting the energy.

1. When Media Coverage Goes Wrong:
â†³ "This gives us a chance to show our real values"
â†³ Draft response pillars - principles beat panic

2. When a Prospect's Team Member Attacks:
â†³ "You're asking exactly what our best clients asked"
â†³ Share specific customer stories - experience beats defense

3. When Board Pushes Wrong Strategy:
â†³ "I appreciate the direction. Let's test some assumptions"
â†³ Share data insights - numbers redirect pressure

4. When Product Launches Fail:
â†³ "Show me where we lost our users"
â†³ Track the drop-off points - data focuses fixes

5. When Team Conflict Explodes:
â†³ "Let's map what success looks like for everyone"
â†³ Create shared vision - alignment calms chaos

6. When a Key Executive Gets Poached:
â†³ "Let's talk about where you want to be in three years"
â†³ Draw their growth path - vision beats immediate offers

7. When Competitors Make Big Moves:
â†³ "This validates our market timing"
â†³ Review your roadmap - confidence beats reaction

8. When Investors Challenge Your Numbers:
â†³ "These metrics tell an interesting story about our market"
â†³ Open your dashboard - storytelling transforms defense to insight

9. When Your Board Questions Strategy:
â†³ "Our customers are showing us something unexpected"
â†³ Share user insights - evidence reframes opinions

10. When Sales Deals Fall Through:
â†³ "Walk me through the decision timeline"
â†³ Map the process - reveals true closing gaps

11. When a Key Customer Threatens to Leave:
â†³ "Help me see the gap between promise and delivery"
â†³ Take notes visibly - problem-solving builds partnership

12. When Cash Flow Gets Tight:
â†³ "Here's our 90-day path to sustainable growth"
â†³ Map three core metrics with team - clarity beats uncertainty

Power isn't in perfect moments.
It's in how you handle the tough ones.

Which phrase saves your next crisis?

Analytics / Data Science / AI Career
Analytics / Data Science / AI Career
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 5 â€“ CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making todayâ€™s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights! The shift from outdated premises to a biomimetic approach is crucial for advancing AGI. Collaboration will be key!

postsData.content:
Beware if your colleague gets the promotion over you and now you report to them. 

If you throw your hat into a management role and your peer gets the position, your days might be numbered. Iâ€™ve heard the story dozens and dozens of times.

Even with peers that were good friends with each other outside of work. Even for peers that covered each otherâ€™s accounts when they took vacation or parental leave.

Now suddenly one is selected for the manager role over the other and there is instant resentment on each side.

The new manager feels threatened by their former peer and challenged with navigating the new relationship. They feel their former peer will be resentful, not loyal to them, sabotage them.

Some new managers may want to make an example of them and exert their power to ensure greater control over the team.

The employee likely feels that they deserved the promotion and perhaps there were other factors other than merit that led to the selection.

They could carry resentment and a negative attitude impacting the morale of the team. They may check out or quite quit while looking for a new job.

Every situation is unique. Iâ€™ve heard it too many times to be an outlier. Both sides should be aware of how things can play out when you don't expect it.

Human nature not at itâ€™s finest.

comments.commentText: Itâ€™s crazy how quickly things can shift when roles change. The dynamic between former peers can get really complicated, and itâ€™s not always about who deserves it more. Navigating those shifts requires a lot of emotional intelligence and open communication.

When I received my Sgt. stripes, a seasoned NCO told me: "If you want to know if you can trust members of your team, try to envision yourself stranded on a deserted island with each one of them indefinitely and you only have one week's worth of food between the two of you. The question then becomes, do you feel comfortable falling asleep knowing they're not going to try and kill you".
It's a twisted way to look at life, but these words of wisdom can be applied to friends, family members, and of course, work associates. Because at the end of the day, even a wolf can dress up in sheep's clothing...
comments.userName: Greg Coulombe, CGR, AKBD, WRT, OCT, FSRT, CGP, CAPS, CGA

Technology Investor Club: Artificial Intelligence, Data Science, Fintech, IoT, Robotics & Cloud AI
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 4 â€“ Update Agent LEARNING
 Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (all links in my comment below)

A report in Quanta magazine provides an example: The idea of a â€œbankâ€ has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. â€œItâ€™s more abstract, really different from what youâ€™re seeing,â€ said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3 of this series.

In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not â€œknowâ€ anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.

I believe there is a massive wakeup call that is coming in the Sales & Revenue space. 

For far too long people/companies have been making massive amounts of money within the sales, revenue, and go-to-market space by strictly providing a product or service that cannot or does not lead to actual REVENUE GROWTH.

I believe those days are coming to end.

Just in the past year since I started my business, I have seen a massive shift in attitudes towards sales & revenue products and services.

This time last year a conversation with a founder looked very much like this:

"I need someone who can come in and provide some strategic guidance on where we are falling short and help show us how to fix the problems."

Now, these conversations with a founder look like this:

"I have 20 people lined up that are saying they can provide me a GTM product or service or advisement that will 'solve' my problems, but I need someone who is willing to come in, get in the weeds, and actually show me that they can increase my revenue."

While you may think this sounds too simple, or that this is a no brainer, most companies are missing the mark here.

How do I know?

I've seen it.

I've experienced it.

Most sales tech do not solve the problem of revenue.

Most sales services do not solve the problem of revenue.

In ways, I've been part of the problem and at times missed the mark myself.

2025 is the year of moving all engagements and focus to one thing...

REVENUE GROWTH

Anything else will not cut it.

postsData.content:
In the last 2 months, I've sat through around 20 hours of interviews 

But after the first 3, I noticed an interesting pattern:

Often, people donâ€™t understand interviews.

So today I thought Iâ€™d share a different perspectiveâ€¦

Hereâ€™s what interviews look like from the perspective of a business owner:

1/ Us

Remember, itâ€™s not just about you.

We care about us.

When weâ€™re hiring, weâ€™re nervous to pick the wrong person.

Itâ€™s expensive.
Itâ€™s very time consuming.
Itâ€™s a risk on our company culture.

And we spend our time hoping to find someone who can make a positive impact on our business.

So youâ€™re not the only person with a lot riding on the interview.

And if you think about it, we all want the same thingâ€¦

You to do as well as you possibly can.

___

2/ It Canâ€™t Just Be For a Job.

When we ask candidates why theyâ€™re applying for a job they have a bad habit of saying things like:

â€Iâ€™m looking for a stable jobâ€.
â€Iâ€™m looking to enter the world after uniâ€.
â€Iâ€™m wanting to start building my careerâ€

And they talk about how they saw the role and it fit their criteria.

But thatâ€™s not what weâ€™re looking for.

I want to know why you want to work for US.

What about our company made you interested?
What about your business got you excited?
What do you think you can bring to us?

And what makes our business your ideal next career move?

This gives you an opportunity to stand out from the crowd with a small amount of research before the interview.

And believe me, it goes a long way.

___

3/ Ideas

Most people walk into interviews with the idea that they should talk about themselves.

But a better way to frame it?

How you, who you are, and your experience can help us.

If you have ideas on how you could help?
â†³ Bring them up and share them.

If you know what kind of impact you could make?
â†³ Clearly explain the value you bring.

And always remember to explain your experience with how that could impact us in mind.

You donâ€™t want this to be the whole interview.

But having the interview framed from that perspective often is why the best candidates stand out.

___

So, thatâ€™s a look behind the scenes, and a few tips for your next interview.

But thereâ€™s 1 thing Iâ€™d be interested to hear:

Would other people hiring give the same feedback? 

---

Anyway, weâ€™re still hiring 

So if you're based in Manchester and want to join a growing team...

Drop me a message!

I'd love to have a chat.

Salespeopleâ€¦ Hereâ€™s what I do if the person Iâ€™ve cold called is not the DM.


1. Ask for the RIGHT person.

Duh. This seems like a no-brainer, but youâ€™d be surprised with how many reps hear, â€œThis isn't my departmentâ€ and then simply hang up.

If you have someone on the phone, and they aren't the right person - at least ASK for the name of the right contact.


2. Ask for an intro.

I know it may seem scary, but you never know their answer until you TRY.

The way I phrase this on a cold call is very simple. It goes like this:

â€œAppreciate you pointing me in the right direction there. Iâ€™m going to send an email to them right now. If itâ€™s not too much to ask though - would you mind if I CCd you on that email, and you just replied there so they know we did in fact ACTUALLY speak haha?â€


This play is not always going to work, but Iâ€™ve found if you actually MAKE the ask, and QUICKLY send over the email as promised - prospects really will reply.

And if you donâ€™t believe me - check out the email I received today.

Navigating Uncertainty: Maintaining a Positive Mindset During Layoff Periods

In recent weeks, I've been reflecting on a challenge many of us in the professional world face: maintaining optimism and productivity while navigating the uncertainty of potential layoffs. Here are some insights I've gained from both personal experience and conversations with colleagues who've weathered similar storms.

First, remember that your value isn't defined by your current employment status. Throughout my career, I've learned that professional setbacks often lead to unexpected opportunities for growth. Whether it's developing new skills, exploring different industries, or discovering hidden talents, periods of uncertainty can become catalysts for positive change.

Focus on what you can control. While company decisions may be beyond our influence, we can control our response to the situation. I've found that updating my portfolio, strengthening professional relationships, and expanding my skill set not only helps maintain a sense of purpose but also builds resilience for whatever comes next.

Stay connected with your network, but be mindful of how you engage. Share knowledge, offer support to others, and maintain authentic relationships. Some of the most valuable connections I've made came from reaching out to help others during their challenging times.

Practice self-care and maintain perspective. It's natural to feel anxious, but don't let worry consume your energy. Regular exercise, mindfulness practices, and setting aside time for activities you enjoy can help maintain emotional balance. Remember, your career is just one aspect of your life.

Most importantly, keep showing up as your best self. Continue delivering quality work, maintain professional relationships, and stay engaged in your current role. This not only helps preserve a sense of normalcy but also demonstrates your resilience and professionalism â€“ qualities that will serve you well regardless of the outcome.

Have you faced similar situations? How do you maintain positivity during uncertain times? I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences in the comments below.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Staying proactive and connected during uncertain times is key. Thank you for sharing these valuable strategies!

My wife is an extremely talented nurse. 9+ years in the ER, 5+ years as a kids transplant coordinator and a short stint as a school nurse during Covid (talking about a bad time to start that job).

The neighborhood go to for fevers, coughs and other ailments that kids tend to have.

Recently she's been interested in going back to the workforce and has been applying to a few openings. Well she found her dream job and applied for it.

Knowing what I know about the job market as we routinely get hundreds of applications for every role we open up I was telling her she needs to do something to stick out.

She doesn't even have aprofile so we went a different route.

Low hanging fruit - email anybody that would be on the hiring team telling them about your experience, passion for patient care and how you'd approach this role.

This was all new to her because typically in nursing you just follow the normal HR process.

I whipped out myaccount and quickly pulled up the 22 contacts who could influence the hiring and dumped them out into a csv which I passed to her.

She typed up a great email, fired it off to all of them and got this response the next day.

Is this going to get her the job? Probably not
If her message gets into the right hands will she have a leg up on the competition? Absolutely
Was it worth the sub 30 minutes it took both of us to do? 100%

If all else is equal in terms of experience, interview, references then this one email might just put her over the edge to landing a dream job.

Worth it.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 5 â€“ CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making todayâ€™s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights! Embracing multidisciplinary expertise is key to revolutionizing AI. Looking forward to seeing this vision evolve!

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 4 â€“ Update Agent LEARNING
Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (all links in my comment below)

A report in Quanta magazine provides an example: The idea of a â€œbankâ€ has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. â€œItâ€™s more abstract, really different from what youâ€™re seeing,â€ said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3 of this series.

In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not â€œknowâ€ anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights! The distinction between human learning and LLMs highlights the potential of mimicking brain processes for AI development. Excited for part 5!

I don't think people are prepared enough for the massive social disruption that AI is going to bring.

Let me be brutally clear: Humans are no longer at the top of the economic food chain.

We are quickly losing the competitive advantages we had over the rest of the animal kingdom (rational thinking),

and we are no longer the best resource that companies can leverage to create shareholder value.

Executives are licking their lips at decreasing their labour costs, increasing their operating margins and mitigating their risks.

Those jobs won't be fully replaced and people will struggle even further to make ends meet than they currently are under this fake 'non-recession'.

Our public systems are already struggling and will likely be cut to reduce the massive debts incurred over the past 10 years.

No-one has a real plan for Universal Basic Income and employers will have their pick of the best displaced talent that are the most desperate for a job.

"Youâ€™re way ahead of where we are."

This comes up often when companies reflect on their AI and data strategy challenges. The reality? Itâ€™s less about being behind and more about navigating unfamiliar territory. Many organizations havenâ€™t yet established a consistent, logical way to represent their data and workflows, making AI feel out of reach.

But the challenge isnâ€™t at the peak of the mountain, itâ€™s at the base. AI and data strategy arenâ€™t about leaping ahead; theyâ€™re about taking deliberate steps toward making better decisions, improving efficiency, and staying competitive.
